I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported the United Nations Convention to 
Combat Desertification (UNCCD), an international treaty aimed at fighting land degradation and 
poverty in dryland areas. Since 1999, ADB has been a member of the Facilitation Committee of 
the  Global  Mechanism  (GM)1 of  the  UNCCD.  The  GM’s  mandate  is  to  promote  effective 
mobilization and use of resources for UNCCD implementation. In close collaboration with other 
members, the GM assists developing member countries in implementing the UNCCD. ADB’s 
regional technical assistance (TA) for combating desertification in Asia2 has supported the 
formulation and implementation of national action plans to fight desertification in arid, semiarid, 
and dry subhumid regions.  
 
2.  ADB was instrumental in the development of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and 
Global Environment Facility (GEF) Partnership on Land Degradation in Dryland Ecosystems, 
which was approved in 2002.3 Subsequently, GEF, members of the Strategic Partnership for 
UNCCD Implementation in Central Asian Countries (SPA),4 and countries of Central Asia asked 
ADB to develop a similar partnership for Central Asia. The Central Asian Countries Initiative for 
Land  Management  (CACILM)  is  under  GEF’s  Operational  Program  on  Land  Degradation 
(OP15).5 In  February  2004,  ADB  led  a  consultation  mission  comprising  multiple  funding 
agencies  to  all  Central  Asian  Countries  (CACs)—Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Tajikistan, 
Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan and cochaired with the GM a workshop in Almaty for the CACs 
and  funding  agencies.  The  workshop  culminated  in  the  agreement  to  move  forward  with 
CACILM  as  a  partnership  among  multiple  countries  and  funding  agencies  to  support  the 
development  and  implementation  of  national  programming  frameworks  (NPF)  for  more 
comprehensive and integrated approaches to sustainable land management in the region. The 
meeting also produced an agreement to establish a task force, comprising representatives of 
the CACs and funding agencies, and to review the concept note and program development 
facility (PDF) application to GEF. Chaired by ADB, the task force also is  to facilitate the design 
of CACILM. In May 2004, GEF approved a concept note to proceed with a PDF application for 
cofinancing the design of CACILM. The task force held its initial meeting on 23–24 August 2004 
to discuss a draft PDF application, and agreed on the TA objectives, scope, terms of reference, 
budget, and implementation arrangements. GEF approved the PDF application for $700,000 on 
31 January 2005. Appendix 1 provides the TA Framework.6

II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Land degradation7 is a serious economic, social, and environmental problem in the 
transition economies of the CACs. It directly affects the livelihood of the rural population by 
reducing the productivity of land resources and undermining the stability, functions of, and 
services derived from natural systems. Agricultural yields reportedly declined by 20–30% across 
the region since these countries achieved independence more than a decade ago, causing as 
much as $2 billion in annual losses in agricultural production. The causes of land degradation 
are multiple and complex, and vary across these countries. However, they are attributed largely 
to the abuse and overexploitation of natural resources, particularly through inappropriate and 
unsustainable agricultural practices such as overgrazing, deforestation, and forest degradation. 
Natural disasters often exacerbate the impact of such practices.  
 
4.  The principal forms and causes of land degradation across the CACs include: (i) erosion, 
salinization, and water logging; (ii) deteriorating fertility of pasture land; (iii) decreased fertility of 
the arable drylands of the steppes; (iv) decreased area and productivity of forests; (v) on-site 
and off-site impacts of mining operations; (vi) exacerbated risks from landslides and flooding 
due to poor watershed management; (vii) reduced stability and functioning of desert, mountain, 
wetland,  and  riparian  ecosystems;  and  (viii)  inadequate  and  incorrect  assessment  and 
monitoring of land degradation. 
 
5.  Efforts to address land degradation generally have had limited success due to: (i) the 
focus on technical solutions; (ii) the lack of coordination across agencies; (iii) inadequate policy, 
legislation, regulation, and incentives for sustainable development; and (iv) inadequate attention 
to  economic  and  social  implications,  and  the  incidence  of  poverty.  The  implementation  of 
measures to control and reverse land degradation through more comprehensive and integrated 
approaches to sustainable land management would generate multiple benefits at local, national, 
and global levels. 
 
6.  Recognizing the challenges of implementing sustainable land management initiatives, 
the GM spearheaded the formulation of the SPA. In mid-2003, the SPA convened a partnership-
building forum in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, bringing together relevant national actors and funding 
agencies to identify the challenges and opportunities for addressing land degradation issues. 
The forum generated the Tashkent Joint Platform of Action for UNCCD Implementation, as well 
as the call to establish in each CAC a working group on partnership development for UNCCD 
implementation. The working groups were established in all of the CACs, and comprise a wide 
range  of  national  actors,  including  line  ministries,  civil  society  organizations,  and  funding 
agencies. 
 
7.  The involvement of GEF, through OP15, is expected to catalyze the mobilization of the 
political  will  and  financial  resources  needed  to  address  these  problems  effectively,  and  to 
achieve incremental global benefits. During the proposed 10-year program, as much as $100 
million in grant funds, depending on the availability of replenishments of GEF, are anticipated to 
be available. 
 
                                                 
7
  Land degradation is defined by GEF as “...any form of deterioration of the natural potential of land that affects 
ecosystem integrity either in terms of reducing its sustainable ecological productivity or in terms of its native 
biological richness and maintenance of resilience.” Cited in GEF. 2003. Operational Program on Sustainable Land 
Management (OP 15).

3 
8.  Given the region’s high vulnerability to land degradation, and the progress in partnership 
formation with the SPA’s support, the CACs are positioned well to cooperate with GEF’s OP15 
in developing an initiative to promote additional measures for addressing land degradation in the 
region. Such an initiative would support: (i) incorporating sustainable land management into 
national development planning processes; (ii) encouraging the adoption of integrated natural 
resource management; (iii) building synergies between the environment and other sectors of the 
economy; and (iv) consolidating and coordinating external financing, while reducing transaction 
costs through the streamlining of partner’s project cycle procedures, among other activities. 
Sources of external assistance, including GEF resources, can be more efficiently and effectively 
allocated to maximize the cost effectiveness of scarce development funds. CACILM will also 
bring benefits to the CACs by supporting the active exchange of knowledge, experience and 
lessons, expertise, and training.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The goal of this program is to combat land degradation and improve rural livelihoods in 
the CACs. The objective is to establish CACILM as a partnership among countries and funding 
agencies to support the development and implementation of NPFs for more comprehensive and 
integrated approaches to sustainable land management in the region. 
 
10.  The TA has four outputs: (i) NPFs for each country, including a prioritized program of 
projects and technical assistance, and related concept papers; (ii) the CACILM partnership brief 
and  supporting  GEF  documentation,  prepared  in  accordance  with  GEF  guidelines  on  the 
programmatic approach; (iii) established mechanisms for consultation and coordination within 
and between countries that enhance the participation of all stakeholders; provide efficient and 
effective  mechanisms  for  the  implementation,  monitoring,  and  evaluation  of  CACILM;  and 
enhance harmonization of funding agencies; and (iv) increased awareness and commitments by 
national and funding agency stakeholders. Key stakeholders in each country will be fully aware 
of the partnership approach, and its advantages and disadvantages. Further, they will commit to 
their respective responsibilities to address land degradation in a comprehensive and integrated 
manner.  Commitments  from  key  stakeholders  and  development  partners  will  be  required 
throughout implementation, with more specific commitments for the first 2 years. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The underlying focus of the approach is to maintain the integrity of this CAC initiative by 
facilitating and strengthening country ownership and drivenness, expanding and deepening 
stakeholder  participation,  and  facilitating  an  expanded  and  transparent  dialogue  with 
development partner agencies. 
 
12.  This approach is to be achieved principally by: (i) ensuring that key national stakeholders 
are fully aware of CACILM and its preparation at all times; (ii) the national working groups’ 
providing the principal entry point for project activities; (iii) extending participation from national 
agencies to communities and land users directly affected by land degradation; and (iv) the task 
force’s providing the required oversight on progress and transparency, and dialogue between 
representatives of the CACs and the partner aid agencies. 
 
13.  The strong participatory approach envisaged for the Project will include regular task 
force  meetings,  with  at  least  one  meeting  in  each  of  the  five  CACs;  two  multi-country

4 
workshops;  national  workshops;  and  regular  working  group  meetings  in  each  country.  In 
addition, national workshops, group interviews, and surveys will form part of an increased and 
sustained  effort  to  engage  the  private  sector,  additional  elements  of  civil  society,  and 
communities and land users directly affected by land degradation in each country. A stakeholder 
participation plan will be prepared at TA commencement to define more precisely the activities 
to broaden stakeholder involvement. 
 
14.  The key activities include: (i) increasing the awareness of national stakeholders, and 
agreeing on the implementation approach at national workshops in each country; (ii) reviewing 
and  analyzing  the  incorporation  of  sustainable  land  management  into  policy,  legislation, 
planning, and budgeting; capacity and institutional arrangements; and the current and planned 
TA and investments in sustainable land management; (iii) preparing NPFs for each country, and 
reviewing and discussing them through national and multi-country workshops; (iv) preparing the 
CACILM  partnership  agreement,  and  reviewing  and  discussing  it  through  multi-country 
workshops  and  task  force  meetings;  and  (v)  agreeing  on  coordination  arrangements  with 
government and funding agency partners, as well as the monitoring and evaluation mechanism 
of the NPFs and the CACILM partnership agreement. The CACILM partnership agreement will 
cover the five CACs and funding agency partners, including GEF. This agreement, together with 
the NPFs, will determine indicative allocations of GEF resources for TA and investments in 
sustainable land management activities. As an executing agency of GEF, ADB—along with 
World Bank, UNDP, and UNEP—is expected to receive substantial resources from GEF to 
support ADB’s TA and lending program in the CACs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million. ADB will provide a grant of $500,000 through its 
TA funding program. GEF and GM will provide grants of $700,000 and $50,000, respectively, 
both  of  which  ADB  will  administer.  The  governments  will  finance  $250,000  through  their: 
(i) provision  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space,  and  facilities;  (ii)  data  and  documents;  and 
(iii) participation in workshops. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The  countries  that  will  be  involved  in  the  TA  are  Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic, 
Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. The TA is expected to commence in April 2005, and 
be completed in December 2005. 
 
17.  The Agriculture, Natural Resources and Environment Division of East and Central Asia 
Department will be the Executing Agency for the TA. ADB will continue to chair the task force, 
which will meet at least three times during the study. In each country, the UNCCD working 
groups will collect and organize information, coordinate with the consulting team, and facilitate 
workshops and government approvals. These working groups are attached to relevant agencies 
in each country: Ministry of Environmental Protection (Kazakhstan); Kyrgyz Research Institute, 
Ministry of Agriculture, Water Resources and Processing Industry (Kyrgyz Republic); State 
Committee for Land Management (Tajikistan); National Institute of Deserts, Flora and Fauna, 
Ministry  of  Nature  Protection  (Turkmenistan);  and  Hydrometerological  Research  Institute 
(Uzbekistan). Development partners under the SPA will participate in national and multi-country 
workshops and task force meetings, and exchange information on the respective strategies and 
programs  in  each  country.  Substantial  material  is  available,  which  has  been  used  in  the 
preparation of country reports under the TA on combating desertification in Asia, and for ADB’s

5 
country environmental assessments. The NPF’s will be based on these documents and the 
national action plan of each country.  
 
18.  Up to 25 person-months of international consultants and 125 person-months of domestic 
consultants will be required. The international consultants will include team leader and natural 
resource  management  specialist  (7  person-months),  land  use  specialist  (6),  policy  and 
institutions specialist (4), sociologist and gender specialist (2), natural resource economist (3), 
and unallocated (3). The domestic consultants will include deputy team leader and natural 
resource  management  specialist  (8),  policy  and  institutional  specialist  (7),  sociologist  and 
gender specialist (7), and unallocated (15, or 3 person-months per country). The unallocated 
person-months  are  to  accommodate  additional  expertise  identified  during  the  study,  or 
extensions  of  some  members  of  the  consulting  team’s  expertise,  if  required.  Individual 
consultants will be engaged in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by 
ADB and its Borrowers, and other arrangements satisfactory for the engagement of domestic 
consultants. Terms of reference for the consulting services are in Appendix 3. Consultants will 
purchase equipment in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. This will include 
computer, printer, and fax, and related accessories as required in each country. The equipment 
will be handed over to the respective agency of the UNCCD working group. 
 
19.  At  least  15  national  workshops,  two  multi-country  workshops,  and  three  task  force 
meetings  will  be  held  during  the  study.  These  workshops  and  meetings  are  designed  to 
increase the participation of stakeholders at national, local, and community levels. The aim is for 
stakeholders to monitor the progress of the study, and ultimately to agree on the NPFs and the 
CACILM partnership agreement. 
 
20.  The team leader will be responsible for submission to ADB, GEF, and the task force an 
inception report within 6 weeks of the Project’s initiation, and two bimonthly progress reports 
(within the third and fifth months of the Project, respectively). Rather than dwelling on routine 
activities, these reports shall provide brief highlights of developments that depart from the 
expectations, and the remedial steps or adjustments envisaged or made. Another key reporting 
requirement will be NPFs for each country, which will cover all aspects of the Project that were 
reviewed and analyzed. An initial format for this report will be agreed upon at the first task force 
meeting, while a revised format will be agreed upon at the first multi-country workshop. The final 
reporting requirement will be the CACILM partnership agreement. Based on the NPFs, this will 
include  the  partnership  arrangements  for  cooperation  and  coordination,  as  well  as  an 
implementation monitoring and evaluation mechanism. The format for this report will be agreed 
upon at the second multi-country workshop. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved: (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by GEF; (ii) ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $50,000 to be financed on a grant basis by GM; and (iii) ADB 
providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for Central 
Asian Countries Initiative for Land Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Team Leader & Natural Resource Management Specialist (7 person-months) 
 
1.  A natural resource management expert will lead a team of international and domestic 
experts in the preparation of national programming frameworks (NPFs) for five Central Asian 
Countries  (CAC),  and  the  development  of  the  Central  Asian  Countries  Initiative  for  Land 
Management  (CACILM)  partnership  agreement.  The  consultant  will  be  qualified  in  natural 
resources management or a related discipline; and will have at least 10 years experience, 
including as a team leader, preferably with substantial experience in Central Asia and/or other 
transition  economies.  The  consultant  will  have  overall  responsibility  for  coordinating  the 
consultant team’s inputs, and for consolidating their outputs at the national and multi-country 
levels. The consultant will report to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) project officer or a 
designate, while maintaining close liaison with the chairs of the five United Nations Convention 
to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) working groups or their designates. 
 
2.  Within the approach described in the Program Development Facility (PDF)-B terms of 
reference  (TOR),  the  specific  responsibilities  of  the  team  leader  and  natural  resource 
management specialist will be to: 
 
(i)  establish  and  maintain  a  communications  network  among  international  and 
domestic  consultants  to  ensure  close  contact,  to  maintain  the  schedule  for 
producing the required outputs, and to establish an efficient system for document 
translation between the two working languages of English and Russian;  
(ii)  serve as the principal liaison for management and communications relationships 
between the consultant team and the ADB project officer, working group chairs, 
and Strategic Partnership for UNCCD Implementation in Central Asian Countries 
(SPA) members; 
(iii)  ensure  that  the  participatory  approach  described  in  the  PDF-B  TORs  is 
implemented  effectively  by  providing  for  wide  stakeholder  involvement 
throughout the design process, especially in the development of the interventions 
to create the enabling environment for progress in addressing land degradation 
and specific complementary on-the-ground investments; 
(iv)  assist with the organization of multi-country and national workshops during the 
design  of  the  CACILM,  including  overseeing  consultant  inputs  to  produce 
necessary  documentation  (in  English  and  Russian)  and  associated  logistical 
support; 
(v)  lead the development of guidelines for use by national working groups for the 
structure  and  contents  of  the  NPF  for  agreement  by,  adaptation  to,  and 
application in each of the five countries, consistent with the elements described 
in the PDF-B proposal; 
(vi)  oversee the inputs of the international consultants and country-level consultant 
teams  in  carrying  out  situation  updates  and  analyses  of  sustainable  land 
management problems and responses as the basis for preparing the NPFs for 
the five countries, and consistent with the specific tasks given in the PDF-B 
proposal and TOR; 
(vii)  supervise preparation of concept papers summarizing the initial round of likely 
investments (to create enabling policy, legal, and institutional conditions, and/or 
to support on-the-ground projects) that will form core elements of the NPFs and

otherwise help with all aspects of consultant team management; and 
(xii)  oversee all logistical aspects of consultant travel and time allocations by task and 
country,  according  to  protocols  for  approvals  and  other  arrangements  to  be 
specified by the ADB project officer. 
 
2.  Land Use Specialist (6 person-months) 
 
3.  A land use specialist will participate on the team of international and domestic experts 
recruited to assist with the preparation of the NPFs and development of the CACILM program 
framework. The consultant will be qualified in environmental science or a related discipline; and 
will have at least 10 years experience, preferably with substantial experience in Central Asia 
and/or in other transition economies. The consultant will have primary responsibility for review 
of, and quality control over, technical dimensions of the diagnostic NPF analysis, especially 
relating  to  land  degradation  problems,  and  responses  and  recommended  approaches  for 
achieving sustainable land management. The consultant will report to the team leader, while 
maintaining close interactions with the five domestic natural resources management specialists 
assigned to each of the national consultant teams. 
 
4.  Within the approach described in the PDF-B TOR, the specific responsibilities of the land 
use specialist will be to: 
 
(i)  use  land  utilization  information  available  from  national  governments  or 
international organizations (possibly supplemented by remote sensing data) to 
prepare  spatial  analyses  by  country  of  land  degradation  that  requires  the 
attention  of  the  CACILM  program.  This  should  include  all  aspects  of  land 
degradation from agriculture (rain-fed and irrigated), pastures and rangelands, 
deforestation, and natural disasters; 
(ii)  determine the role of current land and water management practices in causing 
land degradation, and determine potential reforms to achieve more sustainable 
patterns of land use;  
(iii)  identify important constraints to improving sustainable land use substantially at 
the country level;  
(iv)  assist  with  identification  of  an  action  research  agenda  for  sustainable  lands 
management in Central Asia for potential support under CACILM; and  
(v)  assist with preparation of concept papers summarizing the initial round of likely 
investments (to create enabling policy, legal, and institutional conditions, and/or

12  Appendix 3 
to support on-the-ground projects) that will form core elements of the NPFs and 
will be subject to review and approval once the CACILM program framework is 
agreed upon. 
 
3.  Policy and Institutions Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
5.  An  expert  on  policy  and  institutional  aspects  of  natural  resources  and  economic 
development program design will participate on the consultant team to assist with preparation of 
the NPFs and development of the CACILM partnership agreement. The consultant will be 
qualified in natural resources, environmental economics, or related discipline; and will have at 
least 10 years experience, preferably with substantial experience in Central Asia and/or in other 
transition economies. The consultant will be responsible primarily for reviewing government 
policies  and  legislation  affecting  land  management,  as  well  as  associated  institutional 
arrangements at the national and subnational levels. After the review, the consultant will make 
recommendations for appropriate adjustments to create the enabling conditions for sustainable 
land management and effective project interventions. The consultant will report to the team 
leader,  while  maintaining  close  interactions  with  the  five  domestic  policy  and  institutions 
specialists assigned to each of the national consultant teams. 
 
6.  Within the approach described in the PDF-B TOR, the specific responsibilities of the 
policy and institutions specialist will be to: 
 
(i)  work with the domestic policy and institutions specialist consultants, consultant 
team members, and UNCCD working group members to conduct in each CAC a 
critical review of policies and legislation—as well as the associated government 
and  other  institutions—directly  affecting  the  incentives  for  sustainable  land 
management to identify areas for reform that will create an enabling environment 
for positive policy and institutional reform; 
(ii)   work  with  other  international  and domestic  consultants and  UNCCD  working 
group members to assess the governmental and other institutional arrangements 
for land and water management—including the composition and management of 
the  working  group  itself,  and  the  establishment  of  coordination  centers  for 
sustainable land management—to identify appropriate areas for reform that will 
contribute to a sound enabling environment for sustainable land management; 
(iii)   take the lead in developing policy, legal, and institutional recommendations for 
the NPFs in each CAC, including programmatic objectives, expected outcomes, 
and phasing of proposed actions; 
(iv)   develop, in consultation with other team members, an appropriate strategy and 
specific  measures  common  to  all  participating  countries  for  monitoring  and 
evaluating national and project-level implementation progress, as well as the 
achievement of results, including an agreed set of land management indicators 
for inclusion in the CACILM program framework; 
(v)   oversee preparation of project concept papers summarizing the initial round of 
likely actions and/or investments in policy, legal, and institutional reform, as well 
as  other  measures  needed  to  create  a  strong  enabling  environment  for  all 
investments under CACILM; 
(vi)  work with consultant team members to ensure wide stakeholder involvement 
throughout the design process, especially in the development of interventions to 
create the enabling environment for progress in addressing land degradation; 
and

Appendix 3  13 
(vii)  assist with the organization of multi-country and national workshops during the 
CACILM design process. 
 
4.  Natural Resource Economist (3 person-months) 
 
7.  An expert on land and natural resources economics will participate on the consultant 
team  to  assist  with  preparation  of  the  NPFs  and  development  of  the  CACILM  program 
framework. The consultant will be qualified in resource economics or a related discipline; and 
will have at least 10 years experience, preferably with substantial experience in Central Asia 
and/or in other transition economies. The consultant will be responsible primarily for assessing 
national  planning  and  budgetary  processes  and  trends  to  integrate  sustainable  land 
management into these processes. The consultant also will work with the policy and institutional 
specialists in reviewing government policies affecting land management, as well as associated 
institutional arrangements at the national and subnational levels, from an economic perspective. 
This review will include the impact on the environment and poverty as an input to creating the 
enabling conditions for sustainable land management and effective project interventions. The 
consultant also will take the lead in developing cost estimates for implementing programs under 
the NPFs and the CACILM framework. The consultant will report to the team leader, while 
maintaining  close  interactions  with  the  domestic  policy  and  institutions  specialists  and 
sociologist and gender specialists assigned to each of the national consultant teams. 
 
8.  Within the approach described in the PDF-B TOR, the specific responsibilities of the 
natural resource economist will be to: 
 
(i)  work with the domestic policy and institutions specialist consultants, consultant 
team members, and UNCCD working group members to estimate the costs of 
land degradation conditions to each CAC economy and to vulnerable groups, 
and to project a baseline trend for the future;  
(ii)  review the planning and budgeting processes, as well as expenditure patterns 
and trends on sustainable land management activities, and recommend changes 
within the resource and budgets of the respective countries; 
(iii)  review the debt load and borrowing policies of each country; 
(iv)  analyze, in consultation with other consultant team members, the current and 
planned  projects  and  programs,  identify  appropriate  criteria  for  priority 
investments and technical assistance, and prepare a realistic and sequenced 
program of projects and technical assistance to develop an enabling environment 
and financing of appropriate on-the-ground investments; and  
(v)  serve as the lead consultant for all economic issues associated with policy and 
institutional measures and project development at the national and multi-country 
levels. 
 
5.  Sociologist and Gender Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
9.  An expert on social aspects of land and water resources management, as well as 
associated gender concerns in development program design, will participate on the consultant 
team  to  assist  with  preparation  of  the  NPFs  and  development  of  the  CACILM  program 
framework. The consultant will be qualified in anthropology, sociology or related disciplines; and 
will have at least 10 years experience, preferably with substantial experience in Central Asia 
and/or in other transition economies. The consultant will be responsible primarily for reviewing 
government policies, institutional arrangements at the national and subnational levels, and the 
implications for sustainable land management, food security, poverty, and gender aspects. The

14  Appendix 3 
consultant will recommend appropriate adjustments to create improved conditions for the poor 
and women. The consultant will report to the team leader, while maintaining close interactions 
with the five domestic social scientist and gender specialists assigned to each of the national 
consultant teams. 
 
10.  Within the approach described in the PDF-B TOR, the specific responsibilities of the 
sociologist and gender specialist will be to: 
 
(i)  work  with  the  domestic  social  scientist  and  gender  specialist  consultants, 
consultant  team  members,  and  UNCCD  working  group  members  to  analyze 
social, cultural, poverty, and gender dimensions of land degradation problems in 
each CAC as a critical input to NPFs; as well as background to, and context for, 
the CACILM  program framework; 
(ii)  design, in close consultation with the team leader and consultant team members, 
a participatory approach and tools for interaction with stakeholders, including 
structured and informal interactions ensuring the inclusion of women and gender 
disaggregated data collection; 
(iii)   assist with the assessment of governmental and other institutional arrangements 
for land and water management to identify appropriate areas for reform that will 
contribute to improved conditions for the poor and women; 
(iv)   working with consultant team members, lead the assessment of connections 
between the incidence of poverty and land degradation, as well as a review of 
whether these relationships are reflected in national and sectoral development 
plans; and recommend improved approaches in the NPFs and CACILM program 
framework; 
(v)   work with consultant team members to ensure wide stakeholder involvement 
throughout  the  design  process,  and  lead  the  organization  of  visits  to 
characteristic sites of land degradation and structured and informal interactions 
with target beneficiary groups to enrich the on-the-ground context for the NPFs 
and CACILM program framework;  
(vi)   develop  a  statistical  and  analytical  baseline  of  social  and  gender  conditions 
linked  to  land  degradation,  as  well  as  specific  measures  common  to  all 
participating countries for monitoring results at national and project levels; 
(vii)   prepare a gender plan as part of the NPFs and CACILM program framework, 
including measures for evaluating results, and a strategy for promoting executing 
agency involvement and ownership, and identifying resource requirements; and 
(viii)   contribute to the preparation of project concept papers summarizing the initial 
round of likely investments (to create enabling policy, legal, and institutional 
conditions, and/or to support on-the-ground projects) by providing input on social, 
poverty, and gender issues. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
 
11.  Five national teams of domestic consultants will be engaged with the following expertise:  
 
(i)  deputy  team  leader  and  natural  resource  management  specialist  (8  person-
months); 
(ii)  policy and institutional specialist (7 person-months); and  
(iii)  sociologist and gender specialist (7 person-months).  
 
12.  Detailed terms of reference for each position are available on request.
